title: 115_hr1191
content: The "Child Soldier Prevention Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congress finds the recruitment or use of children in armed conflict unacceptable for any government receiving US assistance. This recruitment continued in various countries during 2015-2016, including Afghanistan, South Sudan, Sudan, Burma, Iraq, Nigeria, Rwanda, Somalia, Syria, and Yemen. The Government of Afghanistan's police forces are involved in counter-terrorism operations and are targeted by opposition groups. The Afghan Local Police and Afghan National Police are recruiting children as combatants or servants, including as sex slaves. In February 2016, a 10-year-old boy was assassinated by the Taliban after being honored by Afghan local police for assisting in combat operations. In South Sudan, government forces have recruited at least 650 children in 2016 and a total of 16,000 since the civil war began in 2013. AMENDMENTS TO THE CHILD SOLDIERS PREVENTION ACT OF 2008. Amendments to the Child Soldiers Prevention Act of 2008 include expanding the definition to include police and other security forces, prohibiting the recruitment or use of child soldiers by governmental armed forces, and requiring notification by the Secretary of State within 45 days of a report submission under the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000. Amendments to the Child Soldiers Prevention Act of 2008 require the Secretary of State to notify governments listed under the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 and certify to congressional committees that governments are addressing the issue of child soldiers effectively. The amendments also modify subsection (e)(1) regarding international military education and training. Amendments to the Child Soldiers Prevention Act of 2008 include reporting requirements for assistance withheld under the prohibition in section 404(a). Amendments to the Child Soldiers Prevention Act of 2008 include reporting requirements for countries under the prohibition in section 404(a). The Secretary of State must include specific information in the annual Trafficking in Persons Report for countries notified or granted a waiver under this Act.
